awd_titl_txt: Function and Evolution of Cognitive Monitoring and Cognitive Control
awd_abstract_narration:
Metacognition is the ability to think about one's own thought processes, which is critical for sophisticated cognition. For example, understanding how well you know a new vocabulary word allows you to decide when to stop studying words as they are learned.  Metacognition involves both monitoring one's own ongoing cognitive processes and exerting cognitive control over them. The proposed research is significant because it will identify the role of cognitive monitoring and control in complex nonhuman primate cognition. This comparative research will advance knowledge of the evolution of complex cognition and of what makes humans unique. The investigators will promote public education about cognitive science and primate cognition through visits to K-12 classrooms and developing an interactive kiosk at the local zoo that allows visitors to experience the same cognitive tests performed by the primates on exhibit. Throughout the research project, undergraduate and graduate students will receive training for careers in science.

Evidence from psychophysical and memory tests indicates that nonhuman primates introspectively monitor some cognitive processes, for example showing selective avoidance of difficult tests. This research will determine the role of cognitive monitoring for cognitive control in primates by examining which cognitive systems are accessible to cognitive monitoring and which are not. Cognitive systems accessible to cognitive monitoring will be distinguished from those that are not by testing for dissociations between accuracy and confidence in tasks involving multiple memory systems contributing to accuracy, and by using psychophysical tests that dissociate motor and perceptual processes. Specific studies address these goals through consideration of 1) the extent to which primates regulate the amount of information they acquire prior to taking tests; 2) what information primates monitor when making metacognitive judgments; 3) the extent to which primates strategically exercise cognitive control only when necessary and adaptively allocate monitoring among competing tasks; and 4) the role of language-like mental representations in cognitive monitoring and control. These comparative studies will determine the extent to which there have been changes in cognitive monitoring and cognitive control through primate evolution.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Scientific Merit
One scientific goal of this work was to determine the extent to which monkeys, like humans, are aware of their thoughts and decision-making processes and can use that awareness to guide adaptive behavior. We found that monkeys engage in "iterative cognitive control" by which they continually monitor developing decisions and decide to act only once they have accumulated sufficient information. This behavior is analogous to humans facing a difficult decision and studying the situation and the options until finding a clear solution.


Another scientific goal was to better understand the extent to which memory systems found in humans exist in monkeys. Humans are aware of the contents of working memory, as when we hold in mind the name of a new acquaintance. In contrast, we often experience a sense of "familiarity" without such specific awareness, as when we meet someone at a party that we are sure we have seen before but we cannot remember who they are or from where we know them. In a series of experiments we found that a similar distinction between working memory and familiarity exists in monkeys. Most important, we found that monkeys are aware of the contents of working memory, and can exert cognitive control on those memories, while the same in not true of familiarity. Similar to the case in humans, working memory is an active process in monkeys, familiarity is passive.


Together these scientific findings inform us about the evolution of awareness of memory in primates, showing that these memory systems, and our ability to become aware of some memories but not others probably evolved at least 30 or so million years ago, when we last shared a common ancestor with rhesus monkeys. These finding also provide powerful new tools for biomedical studies of memory using monkeys as model systems of human memory.


Broader Impacts
We attracted many undergraduate students to cognitive research and provided the resources and guidance they needed to conduct original science that they conceived themselves. Students experienced all stages of the scientific process, from conception to publication, promoting personal investment and encouraging the development of scientific careers. Thus, this work has contributed to training the next generation of cognitive scientists and medical doctors.


This project increased public knowledge of cognitive science in multiple ways. We contributed to an orangutan exhibit at Zoo Atlanta, including information about primate cognition. We have continued to update our recently overhauled website http://www.psychology.emory.edu/lcpc/ where we describe our work, and where we provide demonstrations of the cognitive tests we use with monkeys.


We trained multiple graduate students and several earned their PhDs in the course of the work. Two of those graduate students have taken the computer programming and data analysis skills they learned and applied them to "Big Data" jobs, one in government and one in industry.


Last Modified: 12/28/2021
Modified by: Robert R Hampton
